How are the favourites preparing for the Tour de France 2025?

Now that the Giro d‚ÄôItalia has concluded, the Grand Tour cycle shifts its attention to the biggest competition in the sport: the Tour de France.

Next month, Tadej Pogaƒçar will try to defend his Tour title in the hope of becoming the first rider since Greg LeMond in 1990 to win the Grande Boucle as World Champion. Two-time winner Jonas Vingegaard will have ambitions of derailing this quest after a runners-up spot last year. Likewise, last year‚Äôs third-place finisher Remco Evenepoel will be hoping to improve on his bronze medal, especially with a favourable opening week filled with punchy profiles and a time-trial.

All three will lock horns at the upcoming Crit√©rium du Dauphin√©, but in this day and age, racing isn‚Äôt the only way to build up your Tour de France form. The vast majority of WorldTour pros spend the pre-Tour period at altitude camps across Spain, France or Italy, reaping the physiological benefits from living and training 2,000m above sea level.

Now that we are just a month away from the start of the 2025 Tour de France on Saturday 5th July, it‚Äôs an apt time to dive into each of the favourites‚Äô pre-race strategy. After trawling through Strava, Instagram stories and press interviews, we‚Äôve managed to map out their altitude camps, racing schedule ‚Äì whether that be the Dauphin√© or the Tour de Suisse ‚Äì and other pre-Tour commitments.

Tadej Pogaƒçar (UAE Team Emirates XRG)

The reigning Tour de France champion has had one of the most packed schedules among the Tour favourites. In the spring, he was busy sweeping up Monument titles and even dared to enter Paris-Roubaix.

Since then, Pogaƒçar has been on several altitude camps. In May, he was spotted out in Sierra Nevada alongside some of his Tour domestiques, including Marc Soler, Jo√£o Almeida, Pavel Sivakov and Tim Wellens. He spent several weeks there, fine-tuning his form, and even managed to bump into Jonas Vingegaard, who was also in Spain. This week though, he‚Äôs ventured out to Normandy to recon the route for Stage 5‚Äôs time-trial, which could prove critical in the fight for the yellow jersey.

After his break from racing, the Slovenian will take part in the Crit√©rium du Dauphin√©, which seems to have monopolised most of the Tour favourites this year. This will be his first time at the race since 2020, but it is still one of the few top-tier stage races he is yet to win.

This won‚Äôt be the end of his stringent Tour prep, however. UAE Team Emirates XRG sports director Andrej Hauptman has confirmed that Pogaƒçar still has one altitude camp to complete before heading to the Tour. The location of this camp is unknown, but he spent his final weeks before the 2024 Tour in Isola, close to the French-Italian border.

Jonas Vingegaard (Visma-Lease a Bike)

Jonas Vingegaard started his 2025 calendar in winning ways at the Volta ao Algarve. A month later though, he suffered a wrist injury and concussion at Paris-Nice, which forced him out of the race. Instead of heading to the Volta a Catalunya as previously scheduled, he reshuffled his run-up to the Tour to focus on altitude camps instead of racing.

The Dane, who won the 2022 and 2023 Tour de France, began his official pre-Tour training in Denmark. There, he did wind tunnel testing at an aerodynamic lab in Aalborg in an attempt to improve his time-trial position. After that, he was whisked off to Spain and to his first altitude camp, where he met up with the likes of Victor Campenaerts. Since his almost month-long stint in Spain, he‚Äôs been spotted in Annecy on a training ride the week prior to the Dauphin√©, perhaps in an attempt to scout out some of the climbs that will be included in the final week of this year‚Äôs Tour.

After competing in the Dauphin√©, Vingegaard will return to altitude. This time, he‚Äôll be in Tignes, where Visma-Lease a Bike have been setting up their Tour camp for several years now. As preparations ramp up, his squad for the 2025 Tour seems to have been leaked, given that the Tignes hotel bookings were accidentally revealed by Visma-Lease a Bike staff. With that, we know that Wout van Aert, Matteo Jorgenson, Simon Yates, Edoardo Affini, Victor Campenaerts and Sepp Kuss all have bookings in place for the camp.

Remco Evenepoel (Soudal-QuickStep)

Remco Evenepoel had a later start to his 2025 season after getting slammed by a postman‚Äôs car door during the off-season. After refining form at a training camp in Sierra Nevada, he returned in time for the Classics. Since then, the Belgian has been totting up a decent amount of racing days in one-day competitions and stage races.

After his spring block, he returned to altitude in Spain to continue his preparations. He was initially under the weather at the camp, but refound his form during the multi-week stay in May. There, he was spotted on rides around the mountains and nearby Malaga alongside Louis Vervaeke, Ilan Van Wilder, Tim Merlier and Maximilian Schachmann ‚Äì all of whom we expect to be on the Tour roster. After arriving back home to Belgium at the beginning of this week, Evenepoel has continued to train on home roads, even posting a photo of his golden Specialized Tarmac in front of the Atomium.

Like last year, Remco Evenepoel will compete in the Crit√©rium du Dauphin√©. In 2024, he won the time-trial and went into the yellow jersey briefly before finishing in seventh place overall. The Belgian is said to be nearing ‚Äòhis Tour de France weight‚Äô, approximately 1.5kg lighter than he was 12 months ago. According to his coach Koen Pelgrim, ‚ÄòHe is now one step further than last season just before the Dauphin√©.‚Äô

Although it‚Äôs dependent on what happens in the Dauphin√©, we expect Evenepoel to return to Sierra Nevada for one final tune-up before the Tour de France, which starts on Saturday 5th July in Lille.

The only one of the so-called Big Four not to reach the finishing line last year was Primo≈æ Rogliƒç. Maybe considered to be an echelon below the aforementioned stars, Carlos Rodr√≠guez will be leading Ineos Grenadiers, a team that won seven Tour de France titles during the 2010s.
